--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "jain_prabhat" <jain_prabhat@y...> wrote:
> I am new to J2EE so I might be wrong please let me know.

Turn back while you still have time!  Or at least make sure you don't
jump blindly into the cesspool that is EJB.  

> I am coding in an Eclipse environment, from which I called the JUnit 
> plugin

This is a good thing.

> for testing my test class which has the method as below:
> 
> 	public void testPlain() throws Exception
> 	{
> 		assertEquals(1,1);
> 		assertEquals(2,1);
> 	}
> 
> I always get only the result for last result:
> 
> junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: expected:<2> but was:<1>

Assertions that pass don't do anything.  You only hear about the ones
that fail: no news is good news.
 
> Where as I want to design a test based on the result of first assert 
> and I cannot devide them in to two test beds as the test has to be 
> in single setup-TearDown.

Sorry, but I don't understand this.

I suggest that you do some more in depth reading on JUnit, and ideally
Test-Driven Development (TDD).  I suggest both my own book (TDD: A
Practical Guide) and Johannes Link's (Unit Testing in Java).  If you
pursue TDD (which I strongly encourage you to do) you should read Kent
Beck's as well (TDD: By Example).

> So is there any workaround for this I see lot 
> of examples using multiple asserts in single test case, but why they 
> are not succeeding in my case.

As has been pointing out, it's working just fine.

I'll mention here that I strive to make my test code extremely clean:
my goal is a single assertion per test method.  Best case is to have
all fixture code in setUp() and nothign but a single assertion in each
test method.

Dave
